{{refimprove|date=January 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Inside the Factory | genre = Documentary | presenter = [[Gregg Wallace]]
[[Cherry Healey]] | starring = [[Ruth Goodman (historian)|Ruth Goodman]] | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_series = 4 | num_episodes = 21 (as of 14 August 2018) | list_episodes = #Episodes | producer = Amanda Lyon | runtime = 60 minutes | company = Voltage TV | picture_format = [[16:9]] [[1080i]] | audio_format = [[Stereophonic sound|Stereo]] | network = [[BBC Two]] | first_aired = {{Start date|df=yes|2015|05|05}} | last_aired = present | website = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07mddqk | production_website = http://voltage.tv }} '''''Inside the Factory''''' is a television series produced by Voltage TV for [[BBC]]. Each episode explores how a specific product is made inside a factory. The series is presented by [[Gregg Wallace]] and [[Cherry Healey]], with historian [[Ruth Goodman (historian)|Ruth Goodman]] providing a look at how products came to exist as we know them today. ==Episodes== ===Series 1=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Episode !! Title !! Original airdate !! Viewers (millions) |- | 1 || Bread || 5 May 2015 || 2.35 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Kingsmill]] factory in [[West Bromwich]] to learn the secrets of how they make bread. Cherry looks at how to make your bread last longer and Ruth shows what hidden items used to be found in bread. |- | 2 || Chocolate || 6 May 2015 || 2.45 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg visits the [[Nestlé]] factory in [[York]] and Cherry visits the [[Thornton's]] factory in [[Derbyshire]] to learn the secrets of how they make chocolate. Ruth meets some people who used to work on the first chocolate production lines. |- | 3 ||Milk || 7 May 2015 || 2.54 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Arla Foods|Arla]] factory in [[Aylesbury]] to learn the secrets of how they process milk, Cherry also learns how Cheese is produced and visits [[Unilever]] to learn how they make ice cream. Ruth investigates the history of milk. |} ===Series 2=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Episode !! Title !! Original airdate !! Viewers (millions) |- | 1 || Cereal || 26 July 2016 || 2.43 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Kellogg's]] factory in [[Manchester]] to learn the secrets of how they make cereal, specifically Crunchy Nut Corn Flakes. Cherry also visits the [[Weetabix Limited|Weetabix]] factory, looks at how wheat is grown and how they add additional vitamins and minerals to cereals. Ruth looks at what people used to eat for breakfast before cereal was invented. |- | 2 || [[Crisps]] || 2 August 2016 || 3.07 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Walkers (snack foods)|Walkers]] factory in [[Leicester]] to learn the secrets of how they make crisps, specifically Cheese and Onion. Cherry looks at what makes a perfect potato for making crisps and how your brain can be tricked into thinking you are eating something different. Ruth looks at who invented crisps. |- | 3 ||[[Baked Beans]] || 9 August 2016 || 2.77 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Heinz]] factory in [[Wigan]] to learn the secrets of how they make baked beans. Cherry looks at how cans are recycled and Ruth looks at the history behind canned food. |- | 4 ||[[Bicycles]] || 16 August 2016 || 1.83 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Brompton Bicycle|Brompton]] factory in [[West London (sub region)|West London]] to learn the secrets of how they make folding bicycles. Cherry gets tips from [[Team GB]] to improve her cycling speed and she also learns how bicycles are painted to cope with adverse weather. Ruth looks at important moments in history that used bicycles including the [[D-Day]] landings. |- | 5 ||[[Sweets]] || 23 August 2016 || 3.22 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Swizzels Matlow]] factory in [[Derbyshire]] to learn the secrets of how they make different sweets. Cherry learns how they put writing into [[Rock (confectionery)|rock]] and how different nations have different tastes in sweets. Ruth investigates how sweets were first invented. |- | 6 ||[[Shoes]] || 30 August 2016 || 2.80 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[New Balance]] factory in [[Cumbria]] to learn the secrets of how they make trainers. Cherry looks at how leather is processed as well how ballet shoes are produced. Ruth traces the origins of trainers, specifically to [[Reebok]]. |} ===''Inside The Christmas Factory''=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Episode !! Title !! Original airdate !! Viewers (millions) |- | Special || Christmas || 20 December 2016 || 3.45 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Mr Kipling]] factory in [[Barnsley]] to learn the secrets of how they make various Christmas treats like [[Mince pies]] and [[yule log (cake)|yule log]]. Cherry looks at how tinsel and wrapping paper are made, while Ruth looks at the history of [[Christmas crackers]]. |- |} ===Series 3=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Episode !! Title !! Original airdate !! Viewers (millions) |- | 1 || [[Tea bags]] || 18 July 2017 || 2.45 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Typhoo]] factory to learn the secrets of how they make their teabags. Cherry looks at the process of how the tea leaves first start out before being shipped off to the factories.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b08ywhdn|title=Tea Bags, Series 3, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-01-14}} |- | 2 || [[Pasta]] || 25 July 2017 || 2.52 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry are at [[Barilla Group|Barilla]], the world's largest dried pasta factory in [[Parma]], Italy, where they produce 150,000 kilometres of spaghetti each day.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b08zjhj4|title=Pasta, Series 3, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-01-14}} |- | 3 || [[Biscuits]] || 1 August 2017 || 2.77 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[McVitie's]] factory to look at the production of chocolate [[digestive biscuits]]. Cherry looks at the preparation of the chocolate and the creation of the bronze moulds used to make biscuits.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0906vbt|title=Biscuits, Series 3, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-01-14}} |- | Special || Christmas 2017 || 18 December 2017 || 2.91 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| In this Christmas special, Gregg Wallace, Cherry Healey and Ruth Goodman explore the fascinating factory processes and surprising history behind favourite festive treats. Gregg follows 24 hours of production at a cake factory in Oldham. Meanwhile, Cherry is given special access to Britain's largest marzipan factory. Ruth Goodman adds her own Christmas revelations by investigating how early industrial heritage inspired Charles Dickens to write a Christmas Carol, and why Christmas tree lights are called fairy lights.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09kcx69|title=Christmas 2017, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-01-14}} |- | 4 || [[Fish Fingers]] || 2 January 2018 || 2.94 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg explores the Sealord factory in [[Caistor]] near [[Grimsby]] that processes 165 tonnes of fish a week and produces 80,000 cod [[fish fingers]] every day. Cherry travels to Iceland where they land up to 50 tonnes of cod a day and sees how frozen fish is processed.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09l60v0|title=Fish Fingers, Series 3, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-01-14}} |- | 5 || Sauces || 9 January 2018 || 2.70 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg is in the [[Netherlands]] at a sauce factory that produces a quarter of a million tonnes of condiments every year. Cherry is at a vast factory in [[Maastricht]], where a furnace holding 250 tonnes of molten glass has been running continuously for the last 11 years. Historian Ruth discovers how Brits fell in love with mayonnaise.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09m54qm|title=Sauces, Series 3, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-01-14}} |- | 6 || [[Soft Drink]]s || 16 January 2018 || 3.10 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg explores [[Ribena]]'s [[Gloucestershire]] factory. It turns 90 per cent of Britain's blackcurrants into soft drinks, producing three million bottles a week. Cherry is harvesting the berries on a farm in [[Kent]] - one of 40 that supply the factory. She also heads to the Netherlands to a plant that recycles plastics. Ruth investigates the origins of fizzy drinks.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09p34wt|title=Soft Drinks, Series 3, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-01-14}} |- |} ===Series 4=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Episode !! Title !! Original airdate !! Viewers (millions) |- | 1 || [[Coffee]] || 17 July 2018 || 2.48 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg and Cherry visit the [[Nescafé]] factory in [[Derbyshire]] to learn the secrets of how they make 175,000 jars of freeze dried instant coffee daily. Cherry learns about the chemistry of coffee and Ruth visits the UK's very first coffee house which dates back to 1652.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0bc2cmz|title=Coffee, Series 4, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-07-19}} |- | 2 || [[Toilet paper|Toilet Roll]] || 24 July 2018 || 2.56 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg explores the [[Cushelle]] factory in [[Manchester]] after visiting [[Sweden]] to see how trees are harvested. Cherry visits Britain's oldest toilet factory, where they churn out 1,000 loos a day. Ruth finds out what was used to wipe with before the invention of toilet paper.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0bcr3rj|title=Toilet Roll, Series 4, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-07-19}} |- | 3 || [[Sausage]]s || 31 July 2018 || 2.82 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg explores the Heck sausage factory in [[North Yorkshire]] that produces 625,000 sausages each day whilst Cherry visits the [[University of Chester]] to get the lowdown on getting the best out of our bangers. Historian Ruth Goodman heads to [[Germany]] to establish how sausages came to be.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0bdpy28|title=Sausages, Series 4, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-07-23}} |- | 4 || [[Curry]] || 14 August 2018 || 3.19 |- |colspan="4" align="left"| Gregg explores the [[Sharwood's]] factory in [[Worksop]], [[Nottinghamshire]] which makes 250,000 jars of Curry sauce each day. Historian Ruth takes a look back at the origin of Curry, cooking up a recipe from 1747. Cherry heads to [[Guntur]], [[India]] to harvest chillis and follow them on their journey into powder ready to make up Curry sauce.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0bg6whb|title=Curry, Series 4, Inside the Factory - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-08-08}} |- |colspan="4" align="left"| |- |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|4903514}} * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07mddqk ''Inside the Factory''] at [[BBC Online]] [[Category:2015 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:2010s British documentary television series]] [[Category:BBC television documentaries]] [[Category:BBC high definition programmes]] [[Category:Documentary films about business]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Documentary television series about industry]]

{{Infobox person | name = Joi Ito | image = Joichi Ito Headshot 2007.jpg | caption = Ito in 2007 | birth_name = Joichi Ito | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1966|6|19}} | birth_place = [[Kyoto]], [[Japan]] | residence = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | nationality = [[Japanese people|Japanese]] | alma_mater = [[Tufts University]]
[[University of Chicago]] (attended)
[[The New School]] | occupation = | known_for = [[Blogging]], [[Moblogging]], [[Creative Commons]], [[MIT Media Lab]] | relatives = [[Mizuko Ito]] (sister) | website = {{URL | joi.ito.com | Joi.Ito.com }} }} {{nihongo|'''Joichi''' "'''Joi'''" '''Ito'''|伊藤 穰一|Itō Jōichi|born June 19, 1966}} is a [[Japan]]ese [[activist]], [[entrepreneur]], [[venture capital]]ist, and director of the [[MIT Media Lab]]. Ito is a professor of the practice of media arts and sciences at MIT{{Cite web|url=https://www.media.mit.edu/news/spotlights/2016/06/joi-ito-appointed-professor-practice-media-arts-and-sciences|title=Media Lab Director Joi Ito Appointed Professor of the Practice in Media Arts and Sciences {{!}} MIT Media Lab|website=www.media.mit.edu|access-date=2017-01-08}} and a visiting professor of law from practice at the [[Harvard Law School]].{{cite web|url=http://hls.harvard.edu/faculty/directory/11703/Ito|title=Joichi Ito - Harvard Law School|access-date=2017-07-15}} Ito has received recognition for his role as an entrepreneur focused on [[Internet]] and technology companies and has founded, among other companies, [[PSINet]] Japan, [[Digital Garage]] and [[Infoseek]] Japan. Ito is the chairman of the board of [[PureTech | PureTech Health]].{{cite web | title=PureTech - Our Team | url=http://puretechhealth.com/about.php | accessdate=2015-12-28}} Ito is a strategic advisor to [[Sony]] Corporation,{{cite web|url=https://www.sony.net/SonyInfo/News/Press/201704/17-046E/index.html|title=Press Release: Selection of Board Member Candidates|last=|first=|date=April 28, 2017|website=|accessdate=2013-06-21}} and a board member of [[The New York Times Company]],{{cite web |title=Joichi Ito and Brian McAndrews Join The New York Times Company Board of Directors |url=http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c=105317&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1707618&highlight}} the [[John S. and James L. Knight Foundation]],{{cite web |title=Joichi Ito, Trustee |url=http://www.knightfoundation.org/staff/joichi-ito/ |accessdate=2011-11-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130053916/http://www.knightfoundation.org/staff/joichi-ito/ |archivedate=2012-01-30 |df= }} the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation]],{{cite web |title=MIT Media Lab Director Joi Ito to Serve on MacArthur Board |url=http://www.macfound.org/press/press-releases/mit-media-lab-director-joi-ito-serve-macarthur-board/}} and General Partner of Neoteny Labs.{{cite web|title=Team – Neoteny Labs |url=http://www.neotenylabs.com/about/team/ |accessdate=2010-04-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100411074514/http://www.neotenylabs.com/about/team/ |archivedate=April 11, 2010 }} Ito writes a monthly column in the Ideas section of [[Wired_(magazine)|Wired]].{{cite web |title=Joi Ito | publisher=Wired|url=https://www.wired.com/author/joi-ito/ |accessdate=2018-05-11 }} ==Early life and education== [[File:Joi Ito, circa 1981.jpg|thumb|left|Ito, {{circa}}1981]] Ito was born in [[Kyoto]], [[Japan]]. His family moved to Canada and then when Ito was about age 3 to a suburb of [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], in the [[United States]] where his father became a research scientisthttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HTbjfVdg9vE and his mother a secretary for Energy Conversion Devices, Inc., now [[Ovonics]]. Company founder [[Stanford R. Ovshinsky]] was impressed with Ito, whom he thought of almost as his son. Ovshinsky helped Ito develop his interests in technology and social movements, and at age 13 gave him work with scientists, saying, "He was not a child in the conventional sense."{{cite news|author=Fisher, Lawrence M. |title=The Ambassador from the Next Economy |url=http://www.strategy-business.com/press/freearticle/06309?pg=3 |date=August 2006 |work=strategy+business |publisher=Booz Allen Hamilton Inc. via Internet Archive |accessdate=2012-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208092718/http://www.strategy-business.com/press/freearticle/06309?pg=3 |archivedate=December 8, 2008 }} Ito and his sister [[Mizuko Ito]], who is called Mimi, spent summers in Japan with their grandmother who taught them traditional Japanese culture.{{cite journal |author1=Kelly, Kevin |author2=Rheingold, Howard |title=The Dragon Ate My Homework |url=https://www.wired.com/1993/03/muds-2/ |journal=Wired, the Condé Nast Publications Inc. |issue=1.03 |date=July–August 1993 |accessdate=2007-09-28}} At 14, he returned to Japan when his mother was promoted to president of Energy Conversion Devices Japan. He studied at the [[Nishimachi International School]]{{cite book |author=Rheingold, Howard |title=The Virtual Community: Homesteading on the Electronic Frontier |pages=227 |publisher=The MIT Press |date=2000-11-01 |isbn=0-262-68121-8}} and for high school, the [[American School in Japan]] in [[Tokyo]].{{cite journal |author=Interview |title=The World Wide Blog |journal=Ubiquity, Association for Computing Machinery |volume=5 |issue=25 |date=2004-08-24}} Ito also learned "street language, street smarts, and computers". One of few Japanese using [[modem]]s before [[deregulation]] of networking reached Japan in 1985, Ito had found [[The Source (service)|The Source]] and the original [[MUD1|MUD]] by his teens (and by 26 was working on his own [[MUD]]). Ito returned to the United States to attend [[Tufts University]] as a [[computer science]] major, where he met, among others, [[Pierre Omidyar]], later founder of [[eBay]]. Finding his course work too rigid and believing that learning computer science in school was "stupid", Ito dropped out of Tufts to briefly work for [[Ovonics]]. Ovshinsky encouraged him to return to school. He enrolled at the [[University of Chicago]] in [[physics]] but dropped out on discovering, in his opinion, the program at Chicago to be more oriented towards producing practical engineers than towards teaching an intuitive understanding of physics. In the Fall of 1985 he became the first student to register for a pioneering program of online courses offered by [[Connected Education]], Inc., for undergraduate credit from [[The New School for Social Research]]. Ito is one of [[Timothy Leary]]'s godsons—a close non-traditional family-like relationship, an idea said to have been conceived by Leary for a few of his friends.{{cite web |title=leary.com |work= |url=http://www.leary.com/joiito/ |accessdate=2007-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011051855/http://leary.com/joiito/ |archivedate=2007-10-11 |df= }}{{cite web |title=timothylearyarchives.org |publisher=Timothy Leary Archives Blog |url=http://www.timothylearyarchives.org/interview-with-joi-ito-meeting-tim-collaborating-with-tim-being-tims-godson/ |accessdate=2009-03-04}} Ito's sister is [[Mizuko Ito]], a [[cultural anthropology|cultural anthropologist]] studying media technology use, and the musician [[Cornelius (musician)|Cornelius]] is his second cousin. Ito currently lives in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], with his wife Mizuka Ito (née Kurogane). Joi and Mizuka had a daughter, Kio (輝生) on May 11, 2017. ==Career== Ito became a disk jockey working in nightclubs in [[Chicago]] such as [[The Limelight]] and The [[Smart Bar]] and to work with Metasystems Design Group to start a [[virtual community]] in Tokyo. Later, Ito ran a nightclub in [[Roppongi]], [[Japan]] called [[XY Relax]] with help from [[Joe Shanahan]] of [[Metro Chicago]]/[[Smart Bar]]. He helped bring [[industrial music]] from Chicago ([[Wax Trax! Records|Wax Trax]]) and later the [[rave]] scene, managing a DJ team and visual artists, including importing [[Anarchic Adjustment]] to Japan. [[File:Ito Joichi.jpg|thumb|right|Ito in a 2008 [[Creative Commons]] panel discussion]] Ito was the Chairman of [[Creative Commons]] from December 2006 until 2012. He is on the board of Digital Garage,{{cite web |title=Digital Garage Corporate Information |url=http://garage.co.jp/en/corporate/ |accessdate=2010-04-29}} Culture Convenience Club (CCC),{{cite web|title=CCC Board of Directors |url=http://www.ccc.co.jp/eng/company/profile/executive/ |accessdate=2010-04-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100521161412/http://www.ccc.co.jp/eng/company/profile/executive/ |archivedate=2010-05-21 |df= }} [[Tucows]],{{cite web |title=Tucows Board of Directors |url=http://tucowsinc.com/aboutus/boardofdirectors.php |accessdate=2010-04-29}} and [[Electronic Privacy Information Center|EPIC]],{{cite web |title=EPIC Advisory Board |url=http://epic.org/epic/advisory_board.html |publisher=Electronic Privacy Information Center |accessdate=2008-11-29}} and is on the advisory boards of [[Creative Commons]] and [[Witness (human rights group)|WITNESS]]. He is the founder and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of the venture capital firm Neoteny Co., Ltd. In October 2004, he was named to the board of [[ICANN]] for a three-year term starting December 2004. In August 2005, he joined the board of the [[Mozilla Foundation]]{{cite web |title=About the Mozilla Foundation |url=https://www.mozilla.org/foundation/about.html |accessdate=2010-04-29}} and served until April 2016. He served on the board of the [[Open Source Initiative]] (OSI) from March 2005 until April 2007. He currently serves as a Board Emeritus for OSI.{{cite web |author=Elaina Hamilton |title=Joichi Ito Education |url=http://digital.uncg.edu/390/elaina_hamilton/ji1education.html |accessdate=2016-03-16}} He was a founding board member of Expression College for Digital Arts{{cite web |title=People at Expression:Joi Ito |url=http://expression.edu/about_us/individual/C35/joi_ito |publisher=Expression College for Digital Arts |accessdate=2007-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008200751/http://expression.edu/about_us/individual/C35/joi_ito |archivedate=2007-10-08 |df= }} as well as the Zero One Art and Technology Network.{{cite web |title=ZERO1 Board |url=http://01sj.org/?page_id=26 |publisher=ZERO1 |accessdate=2007-09-28}} In 1999, he served as the Associate to Mr. Mount (the executive producer) on the film ''[[The Indian Runner]]''.{{cite web |title=The Indian Runner (1999) Full Cast and Crew |work=IMDB |url=http://imdb.com/title/tt0102116/fullcredits#cast |accessdate=2007-09-27}} Ito also served as a Board Member of [[Ovonics|Energy Conversion Devices]] from 1995 to 2000. Ito is a venture capitalist and [[angel investor]] and was an early stage investor in [[Kickstarter]],{{cite web |title=Kickstarter Fesses Up: The Crowd-Sourced Funding Startup Has Funding Too |url=http://mediamemo.allthingsd.com/20110317/kickstarter-fesses-up-the-crowd-sourced-funding-startup-has-funding-too/}} [[Twitter]],{{cite web |title=Twitter in Japan |url=http://blog.twitter.com/2008/01/twitter-in-japan.html |accessdate=2010-04-29}} [[Six Apart]], [[Technorati]], [[Flickr]], [[SocialText]], [[Dopplr]], [[Last.fm]], [[Rupture (social networking)|Rupture]], [[Kongregate]], [[Fotopedia]], [[Diffbot]], [[Formlabs]], [[3Dsolve]] and other Internet companies.{{cite web |title=Joi Ito |work=Joi Ito's Wiki |url=http://joiwiki.ito.com/joiwiki/index.cgi?joi_ito |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819042954/http://joiwiki.ito.com/joiwiki/index.cgi?joi_ito |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-08-19 |accessdate=2007-09-27 }}Joi Ito Crunchbase http://www.crunchbase.com/person/joi-ito A vocal advocate of [[emergent democracy]] and the [[sharing economy]], Ito is a [[Doctor of Business Administration|doctoral candidate]] in [[Business Administration]] focusing on the [[gift economy|sharing economy]] at the [[Graduate School of International Corporate Strategy]], [[Hitotsubashi University]]. He is the author of ''[[emergent democracy|Emergent Democracy]]''.{{cite web |author=Ito, Joichi |title=Emergent Democracy (Version 1.32) |url=http://joiwiki.ito.com/joiwiki/index.cgi?emergent_democracy |date=June 28, 2003 |publisher=Socialtext |accessdate=May 4, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120712205608/http://joiwiki.ito.com/joiwiki/index.cgi?emergent_democracy |archivedate=July 12, 2012 |df= }} and {{cite book |author1=Lebkowsky, Jon |author2=Ratcliffe, Mitch |title=Extreme Democracy |pages=13–39 |publisher=Lulu.com |year=2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MDC9izjKyUMC |isbn=1-4116-3139-0 |accessdate=May 4, 2010 }} Ito is Senior Visiting Researcher of Keio Research Institute at SFC.{{cite web |title=Program: Electronic Media – Challenges and Opportunities |publisher=Higher Colleges of Technology |url=http://www.hct.ac.ae/pdfs/electronic%20media%20conf%20program.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-11-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081230092127/http://www.hct.ac.ae/pdfs/electronic%20media%20conf%20program.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-30 |df= }} In May 2011, it was announced that Ito's company, Digital Garage, will provide PR, marketing, product marketing research and market research for [[Linkedin]] Japan.{{cite web |url=http://www.penn-olson.com/2011/05/27/linkedin-japan-2/ |title=LinkedIn Has Value Preposition to Succeed in Japan, Digital Garage to Help | Penn Olson |work=penn-olson.com |year=2011 |quote=Joi |accessdate=2 June 2011}} Ito is a [[Professional Association of Diving Instructors|PADI]] IDC Staff Instructor, an Emergency First Responder Instructor Trainer, and a [[Divers Alert Network]] (DAN) Instructor Trainer.{{cite web |title=Joichi Ito LinkedIn Profile |work=LinkedIn |url=http://www.linkedin.com/in/joiito |accessdate=2011-09-10}} In recent years, Ito has become critical of what he sees as Japan's inward focus. He stated in a 2011 interview that he thinks Japan needs to look internationally if it is to continue to be "relevant".{{cite web |url=http://www.timeout.jp/en/tokyo/feature/3543/The-Hot-Seat-Joi-Ito |title=Joi Ito: The Interview |accessdate=8 July 2011 |last=Wilks |first=Jon |date=May 31, 2011 |work=Time Out Tokyo|publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706153739/http://www.timeout.jp/en/tokyo/feature/3543/The-Hot-Seat-Joi-Ito |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df= }} ===Journalism=== Ito has written opinion [[editorial]]s for the Asian ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''{{cite web |title=Japan Reform and Recovery |work=Joi Ito's Web (blog) |date=April 7, 2002 |url=http://joi.ito.com/archives/2002/04/09/trilateral_commission_speech.html |accessdate=2007-09-29}} and ''[[The New York Times]]''{{cite news |title=An Anniversary to Forget |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 7, 2005 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/07/opinion/07ito.html?ex=1281067200&en=e6b897762b09f727&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss |accessdate=2007-09-27 |first=Joichi |last=Ito}}{{cite news |title=In Japan, Stagnation Wins Again |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 18, 2007 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/18/opinion/18ito.html?ex=1347768000&en=da38c67fa3aa329c&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss |accessdate=2007-09-27 |first=Joichi |last=Ito}} and has published articles in numerous other magazines{{cite news |title=World of Warcrack |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/14.06/warcraft.html |date=June 2006 |accessdate=2007-09-27}} and newspapers. He has had regular columns in ''[[Yomiuri Shimbun|The Daily Yomiuri]]'', ''[[Macworld|Mac World Japan]]'', ''[[Asahi Shimbun|Asahi]] Pasocom'', ''Asahi Doors'', and other media sources. His photographs have been used in ''[[The New York Times]]'' Online,{{cite news |title=For Jobs and Gates, a Night to Reminisce |work=[[New York Times]] |date=May 31, 2007 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/31/technology/31digital.html?ex=1338264000&en=6225f0854662fa74&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss |accessdate=2007-09-27 |first=John |last=Markoff}} ''[[BusinessWeek]]'',{{cite web |title=Entrepreneurs for the Ages |work=[[BusinessWeek]] |url=http://images.businessweek.com/ss/07/06/0628_greatest_entp/index_01.htm |accessdate=2007-09-27}} ''[[American Heritage (magazine)|American Heritage]]'',{{cite web |title=The Birth of EBay |work=AmericanHeritage.com |url=http://www.americanheritage.com/events/articles/web/20070903-ebay-omidyar-meg-whitman-internet-e-commerce-consumer-to-consumer-c2c-disintermediation-world-wide-web.shtml |accessdate=2007-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070906054117/http://www.americanheritage.com/events/articles/web/20070903-ebay-omidyar-meg-whitman-internet-e-commerce-consumer-to-consumer-c2c-disintermediation-world-wide-web.shtml |archivedate=2007-09-06 |df= }} [[Wired News]],{{cite news |author=Schiffman, Betsy |title=Twitter CEO on How the Company Will Make Money: Ummm |url=http://blog.wired.com/business/2008/11/evan-williams-c.html |date=November 6, 2008 |work=Wired News |publisher=CondéNet |accessdate=November 6, 2008}} [[Forbes]],{{cite news |author=Griffiths, Daniel Nye |title=It Takes Tweets to Tango – Murdoch, Kutcher, the ur-Jack and the dangers of Twitter |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/danielnyegriffiths/2012/01/16/murdoch-dorsey-twitter/ |date=January 16, 2012 |publisher=Forbes.com |accessdate=January 16, 2012}} and [[BBC News]].{{cite news |author=Waters, Darren |title=Stark warning for internet's future |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/7364901.stm |date=April 24, 2008 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2008-04-28}} He was on the early editorial mastheads of ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' and ''[[Mondo 2000]]''. He has authored and co-authored a number of books including ''Dialog – Ryu Murakami X Joichi Ito'' with [[Ryu Murakami]], and "Freesouls: Captured and Released" with [[Christopher Adams (author)|Christopher Adams]], a book of Ito's photographs that includes essays by several prominent figures in the [[free culture movement]].[http://freesouls.cc/ Freesouls] He has hosted televisions shows including ''The New Breed'' and ''SimTV'' shows on [[NHK]]. He is currently the host of a TV show called "Super-Presentation" airing weekly in Japan on [[NHK]].{{cite web |title=スーパープレゼンテーション｜Eテレ NHKオンライン |url=http://www.nhk.or.jp/superpresentation/ |accessdate=2014-03-12}} ===Recognition and honors=== Ito was listed by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine as a member of the "Cyber-Elite" in 1997. He was also named one of the 50 "Stars of Asia" in the "Entrepreneurs and Dealmakers" category by ''[[BusinessWeek]]''{{cite news |title=The Stars of Asia (int'l edition) |work=BusinessWeek |date=July 3, 2000 |url=http://www.businessweek.com/2000/00_27/b3688009.htm |accessdate=2007-09-16}} and commended by the [[Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications|Japanese Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications]] for supporting the advancement of IT in 2000.{{cite web |title=The Markets Are Stupid. The Current Internet Valuations Have Very Little to Do With the Actual Value of the Companies. |work=Joi Ito's Web |url=http://joi.ito.com/archives/2000/09/01/the_markets_are_stupid_the_current_internet_valuations_have_very_little_to_do_with_the_actual_value_of_the_companies.html#more |accessdate=2007-09-27}} He was selected by the [[World Economic Forum]] in 2001 as one of the "Global Leaders for Tomorrow"{{cite news |title=Economic Forum Entrepreneurs – Japanese put on list of world's 100 young leaders |work=Kyodo World News Service |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-49951646.html |date=February 3, 2002 |accessdate=2007-09-27}} and chosen by ''[[Newsweek]]'' as a member of the "Leaders of The Pack (high technology industry)" in 2005,{{cite news |title=Leaders of The Pack (high technology industry) |work=Newsweek International |date=April 25, 2005 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-131693906.html |accessdate=2007-09-27}} and listed by ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' as a member of "The Next Establishment" in the October Issue, 2007{{cite news |title=Vanity Fair (Re) Discovers Tech |work=Vanity Fair |date=October 2007 |url=http://gigaom.com/2007/09/13/vanity-fair-2007-new-establishment/ |accessdate=2007-09-27}} and 2011.{{cite news |title=Vanity Fair Next Establishment 2011 |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/business/new-establishment/2011/next-establishment-201110 |date=October 2011 |accessdate=2012-09-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923161123/http://www.vanityfair.com/business/new-establishment/2011/next-establishment-201110 |archivedate=2011-09-23 |df= }} Joi Ito was also named by ''BusinessWeek'' as one of the 25 Most Influential People on the Web in 2008.{{cite news |title=The 25 Most Influential People on the Web: The Adviser: Joi Ito |work=BusinessWeek |date=September 29, 2008 |url=http://images.businessweek.com/ss/08/09/0929_most_influential/9.htm |accessdate=2008-10-11}} On July 22, 2011 he was awarded a Lifetime Achievement Award in recognition of his role as one of the world's leading advocates of Internet freedom from the University of [[Oxford Internet Institute]].{{cite news |title=Director of MIT Media Lab Joi Ito Receives Lifetime Achievement Award from the Oxford Internet Institute |date=July 22, 2011 |url=http://www.oii.ox.ac.uk/news/?id=566 |accessdate=2011-08-09}} In 2011, with [[Ethan Zuckerman]], he was named by ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' magazine to its list of top global thinkers, in which he stated the ''Best idea'' is "Users controlling their own data".{{cite news |title=The FP Top 100 Global Thinkers |date=November 28, 2011 |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2011/11/28/the-fp-top-100-global-thinkers-4/ |accessdate=May 13, 2016}} Ito received the degree of [[Doctor of Letters|Doctor of Literature]], honoris causa, from [[The New School]] in 2013.{{cite news |title=Honorary Degree Recipients |date=2013-05-24 |url=http://www.newschool.edu/commencement/honorary-degree-recipients/ |accessdate=2013-05-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130324005535/http://www.newschool.edu/commencement/honorary-degree-recipients/? |archivedate=2013-03-24 |df= }} On March 11, 2014, Ito was inducted into the SXSW Interactive Festival Hall of Fame.{{cite web |title=SXSW Interactive Festival Hall of Fame Honors Top Industry Trendsetters: 2014 Inductee is Joi Ito |url=http://sxsw.com/interactive/awards/hall-of-fame |accessdate=2014-03-12}} He was a [[TED (conference)|TED]] speaker at the March 21, TED2014.[http://blog.ted.com/2014/03/21/instead-of-futurists-lets-be-now-ists-joi-ito-at-ted2014/ Instead of futurists, let’s be now-ists: Joi Ito at TED2014] In 2014, Ito was awarded the [[List of Golden Plate awardees|Golden Plate Award]] by the [[Academy of Achievement]].{{cite web |title=2009 – 2014 Golden Plate Recipients |work=Academy of Achievement |url=http://www.achievement.org/autodoc/pagegen/brochure/p4.html |accessdate=2014-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014040049/http://www.achievement.org/autodoc/pagegen/brochure/p4.html |archivedate=2014-10-14 |df= }} On May 17, 2015 Ito received a [[Doctor of Humane Letters]], honoris causa, from [[Tufts University]].{{cite news |title=Commencement 2015: Biographies – Joichi "Joi" Ito |url=https://now.tufts.edu/commencement2015/biographies/ito|date=May 17, 2015 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} Ito was elected to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in April 2017. http://news.mit.edu/2017/eleven-from-mit-elected-american-academy-arts-and-sciences-0412On May 11, 2017 Ito was awarded the [[IRI Medal]].{{cite news|title=Joi Ito, MIT Media Lab Director, Awarded the IRI Medal|url=http://www.iriweb.org/articles/joi-ito-mit-media-lab-director-awarded-iri-medal|accessdate=2017-05-26}} ===MIT Media Lab=== ''The New York Times'' reported in April 2011 that Joi Ito was named to be the director of the [[MIT Media Lab]]. His appointment was called an "unusual choice" since Ito studied at two colleges, but did not finish his degrees. "The choice is radical, but brilliant," said [[Larry Smarr]], director of [[California Institute for Telecommunications and Information Technology|Calit2]].{{cite news |author=Markoff, John |title=M.I.T. Media Lab Names a New Director |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/26/science/26lab.html |date=April 25, 2011 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=April 25, 2011}} Ito officially began his role on September 1, 2011.{{cite web |work=Joi Ito's Twitter Stream |title=I'm finally "officially" the Director of the MIT @medialab and here's my first blog post on the new Media Lab blog: |url=https://twitter.com/Joi/status/109243735891656704 |date=September 1, 2011}}{{cite news |author=Kirsner, Scott |title=MIT picks Joichi Ito, Japanese venture capitalist and entrepreneur, as new leader of the Media Lab |url=http://www.boston.com/business/technology/innoeco/2011/04/mit_picks_joichi_ito_japanese.html |date=April 26, 2011 |work=Boston.com (The Boston Globe) |publisher=The New York Times Company |accessdate=April 26, 2011}} He was appointed Professor of the Practice of Media Arts and Sciences at MIT, effective July 1, 2016.{{cite web |title=Media Lab Director Joi Ito Appointed Professor of the Practice of Media Arts and Sciences |date=June 2016 |URL=https://www.media.mit.edu/news/spotlights/2016/06/joi-ito-appointed-professor-practice-media-arts-and-sciences |accessdate=2016-06-13}} [[Nicholas Negroponte]], Media Lab's co-founder and chairman emeritus, described the choice as bringing the media to "Joi's world".{{cite news |title=Joichi Ito named director of MIT Media Lab |url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2011/ito-media-lab-director.html |date=April 25, 2011 |work=MIT News |publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology |accessdate=April 25, 2011}} In an interview with [[Asian Scientist Magazine]], Joi Ito discusses his vision for the MIT Media Lab, and how he likes the word “learning” better than the word “education”.{{cite news |author=Chan, Juliana |title=Newly Appointed MIT Media Lab Director, Joichi Ito, Talks To Asian Scientist |url=http://www.asianscientist.com/features/joichi-ito-executive-director-mit-media-lab/ |date=May 2, 2011 |work=AsianScientist.com |accessdate=May 14, 2011}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book | last=Ito | first=Joi | author-link=Joi Ito | last2=Howe | first2=Jeff | year=2016 | title=Whiplash: How to Survive Our Faster Future | publisher=Grand Central Publishing |ISBN=978-1455544592 }} * {{cite book | last=Ito | first=Joi | author-link=Joi Ito | year=2008 | title=FREESOULS: Captured and Released | publisher=Freesouls.cc |ISBN=978-0982029121 }} ==See also== {{Portal|Japan|Biography|Business}} * [[History of the Japanese in Metro Detroit]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Ito Joichi}} * [http://joi.ito.com/ Official webpage] * [http://joi.ito.com/jp/ Official webpage] {{ja icon}} * [https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/whiplash-how-to-survive-our-faster-future/ Book announcement for "Whiplash"] * {{IMDb name|1385567|Jôichi Itô}} * {{TED speaker}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yB5wLVnhJLU Joichi Ito Interview Video] * [http://mikeypod.com/2016/12/19/mikeypod-221-mit-media-lab-director-author-joi-ito/ Joichi Ito on the MikeyPod Podcast] revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=May 2012}}
'''Lights For Learning''' is a British-based [[Charitable organization|charity]] founded in 2000. They provide solar powered electric lighting to places of education with no access to artificial light, mainly in rural [[Africa]]n [[school]]s. The organisation received registered charity status in 2004 and has now fitted schools in several African countries and the Philippines with their unique lighting system.
==External links== * http://www.lightsforlearning.org * http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/
[[Category:Development charities based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Education in Africa]] [[Category:Energy-saving lighting]] [[Category:Solar power]]

revision.comment: One of the projects was listed as being under construction. As of October 2018, the project has been completed and opened to the public, so I amended the listing to reflect that it wa no longer under construction.

{{Multiple issues| {{original research|date=March 2015}} {{cleanup|reason=Outdated.|date=March 2017}} }} {{expand list|date=March 2015}} This is a '''list of transport megaprojects'''. Care should be taken in comparing the cost of projects from different times, even a few years apart due to [[inflation]]; comparing [[Real versus nominal value (economics)|nominal]] costs without taking this into account can be highly misleading. The size and scope of projects varies considerably; some projects are made up of a package of different infrastructure projects, while others may be single part of a larger network. In order to limit the size and scope of this list, recent infrastructure that cost less than [[USD|$]]1 billion is not listed; this is a common definition of a [[megaproject]]. However, historically significant projects may be listed. See also [[list of megaprojects]]. ==Completed projects== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! width="140"|Project ! width="180"|Description ! width="180"|Location ! data-sort-type="currency"|Approximate cost (in billions [[USD]]) ! align="center"|Start of construction ! align="center"|Year of completion ! align="center"|Image ! width="180"|Notes |- | [[AVE|AVE - {{See also|Passive house}} [[Image:Passivhaus thermogram gedaemmt ungedaemmt.png|thumb|350px|A [[thermogram]] compares the "heat radiation" of the windows and walls of two buildings: sustainable low-energy [[passive house]] (right) and conventional leaking house (left)]] A '''low-energy house''' is any type of house that from design, technologies and building products uses less energy, from any source, than a traditional or average contemporary house. In the practice of [[sustainable design]], [[sustainable architecture]], [[low-energy building]], [[energy-efficient landscaping]] low-energy houses often use [[active solar]] and [[passive solar building design]] techniques and components to reduce their energy expenditure.
==General usage== The meaning of the term 'low-energy house' has changed over time, but in [[Europe]] it generally refers to a house that uses around half of the German or Swiss low-energy standards referred to below for [[space heating]], typically in the range from 30 kWh/m²a to 20 kWh/m²a (9,500 Btu/ft²/yr to 6,300 Btu/ft²/yr). Below this the term 'Ultra-low-energy building' is often used.
The term can also refer to any dwelling whose energy use is below the standards demanded by current [[building code]]s. Because national standards vary considerably around the world, 'low-energy' developments in one country may not meet 'normal practice' in another.
==National standards== In some countries the term relates to a specific building standard.<ref>Raad Z. Homod, (2014) “Assessment regarding energy saving and decoupling for different AHU (air handling unit) and control strategies in the hot-humid climatic region of Iraq” [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S036054421400869X Energy, 74 (2014) 762-774]</ref> In particular, these seek to limit the energy used for space heating, since in many [[climate zone]]s it represents the largest energy use. Other energy use may also be regulated. The [[history of passive solar building design]] gives an international look at one form of low-energy building development and standards.
=== Europe === In [[Germany]] a low-energy house ''(Niedrigenergiehaus)'' has a limit equivalent to 7 litres of heating oil for each square metre of room ''for space heating'' annually (50 kWh/m²a or 15,850 Btu/ft²/yr). In [[Switzerland]], the term is used in connection with the ''MINERGIE'' standard (42 kWh/m²a or 13,300 Btu/ft²/yr) or the Minergie-P (equivalent to the Passivhaus).
In comparison, the German ''[[Passivhaus]]'' ultra-low-energy standard, currently undergoing adoption in some other [[Europe]]an countries, has a maximum space heating requirement of 15 kWh/m²a or 4,755 Btu/ft²/yr.
A "sub-10 passive house" is under construction in Ireland that has an independently evaluated PHPP (Passive House) rating of 9.5 kW/m<sup>2</sup>/year. Its form of construction also tackles the issue of [[embodied energy]], which can significantly distort the lifecycle CO<sub>2</sub> emissions associated with even low energy use houses.
=== North America ===
==== United States ====
In the United States, the [[Energy Star|ENERGY STAR]] program is the largest program defining low-energy homes and [[consumer product]]s. Homes earning ENERGY STAR certification use at least 15% less energy than standard new homes built to the International Residential Code, although homes typically achieve 20%–30% savings.<ref>[http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=new_homes.nh_features "Features of ENERGY STAR Qualified New Homes."] - EnergyStar.gov, Retrieved 7 March 2008.</ref>
In addition, the US Department of Energy launched a program in 2008 with the goal of spreading zero-energy housing over the US. Currently, participating builders commit to constructing new homes that achieve 30% savings on a [[home energy rating]] scale.<ref>[http://www1.eere.energy.gov/buildings/challenge/about.html "About Builders Challenge."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903011241/http://www1.eere.energy.gov/buildings/challenge/about.html |date=2011-09-03 }} - March 2008. Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, U.S. Department of Energy. Retrieved 7 March 2008.</ref>
==== Canada ====
In Canada, builders may voluntarily use a range of standards, labels, and certification programs to demonstrate that they have achieved a very high level of energy performance in a given project. These include:
* [http://www.chba.ca/nze The Net Zero Home] and [http://www.chba.ca/nze Net Zero Ready Home] certifications, administered by the [http://www.chba.ca Canadian Home Builders Association]. * [http://www.builtgreencanada.ca/about-our-programs Built Green] labels, administered by [http://www.builtgreencanada.ca/ Built Green Canada]. * [http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/energy/efficiency/housing/new-homes/5057 Energy Star for Homes], administered by [http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/ Natural Resources Canada]. * The [http://www.passivehouse.ca/ Canadian Passive House] standard, administered by the [http://www.passivehouse.ca/ Canadian Passive House Institute].
In British Columbia, all of the above programs align with the [[BC Energy Step Code]], a provincial regulation that local governments may use, if they wish, to incentivize or require a level of energy efficiency in new construction that goes above and beyond the requirements of the base building code. The BC Energy Step Code is designed as a technical roadmap to help the province reach its target that all new buildings will attain a net zero energy ready level of performance by 2032.
==Zero-energy and energy-plus buildings== Beyond ultra-low-energy buildings are those that use, on average over the course of a year, no imported energy - [[zero-energy building]]s – or even those that generate a surplus - [[energy-plus house]]s – both of which have been and are being successfully built.
This can be achieved by a mixture of [[energy conservation]] technologies and the use of [[renewable energy]] sources. However, in the absence of recognized standards, the mix between these – and consequently the energy-use profile and environmental impact of the building – can vary significantly.
At one end of the spectrum are buildings with an ultra-low space heating requirement that therefore require low levels of imported energy, even in winter, approaching the concept of an [[autonomous building]].
At the opposite end of the spectrum are buildings where few attempts are made to reduce the space heating requirement and which therefore use high levels of imported energy in winter. While this can be balanced by high levels of renewable energy generation throughout the year, it imposes greater demands on the traditional national energy infrastructure during the peak winter season. *[[Zero-energy building]] *[[Superinsulation]] *[[PlusEnergy]]
==Low-energy technology==
=== Introduction === {{Main article|List of low-energy building techniques}} {{For|history and further detail|Zero energy building|Passivhaus}} Low-energy buildings typically use high levels of [[Building insulation|insulation]], energy efficient [[Insulated glazing|window]]s, low levels of air infiltration and [[heat recovery ventilation]] to lower heating and cooling energy. They may also use [[passive solar building design]] techniques or [[active solar]] technologies. These homes may use [[hot water heat recycling]] technologies to recover heat from showers and dishwashers. Lighting and [[miscellaneous electric load|miscellaneous]] energy use is allieviated with [[fluorescent lamp|fluorescent lighting]] and efficient appliances. [[Weatherization]] provides more information on increasing building energy efficiency.
[[Passive House]]s are required to achieve a whole building [[air changes per hour|air change rate]] of no more than 0.6 ac/hr <ref name="Passivhaus_ac">{{cite web |url = http://www.passivehouse.com/English/PassiveH.HTM |title = What is a Passive House? |accessdate = 2010-05-02 |last = Feist |first = Wolfgang |authorlink = Wolfgang Feist |publisher = Passivhaus Institut |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20030906202457/http://www.passivehouse.com/English/PassiveH.HTM |archivedate = 2003-09-06 |df = }}</ref> <ref group=footnote name="ac/hr">ac/hr = air changes per hour; "''air change''" refers to the house volume</ref> under forced pressurisation and depressurisation testing at 50Pa minimum. On site blower door testing by certified testers is used to prove compliance.
A significant feature of ultra-low-energy buildings is the increasing importance of heat loss through linear thermal bridging within the construction. Failure to eliminate thermal pathways from warm to cold surfaces ("bridges") creates the conditions for [[interstitial condensation]] forming deep within the construction and lead to potentially serious issues of mould growth and rot. With near zero filtration losses through the fabric of the dwelling, air movement cannot be relied upon to dry out the construction and a comprehensive condensation risk analysis of every abutment detail is recommended.
=== Improvements to heating, cooling, ventilation and water heating === {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * [[Absorption refrigerator]] * [[Annualized geothermal solar]] * [[Earth cooling tubes]] * [[Geothermal heat pump]] * [[Heat recovery ventilation]] * [[Hot water heat recycling]] {{col-2}} * [[Passive cooling]] * [[Renewable heat]] * [[Seasonal thermal energy storage]] (STES) * [[Solar air conditioning]] * [[Solar hot water]] * [[:Category:Solar powered devices|Solar devices]] {{col-end}}
===Passive solar design and landscape=== [[Passive solar building design]] and [[energy-efficient landscaping]] support the low-energy house in conservation and can integrate them into a [[neighborhood]] and environment. Following [[List of low-energy building techniques|passive solar building techniques]], where possible buildings are compact in shape to reduce their surface area, with principal windows oriented towards the equator - south in the northern hemisphere and north in the southern hemisphere - to maximize passive [[solar gain]]. However, the use of solar gain, especially in [[temperate]] [[climate]] regions, is secondary to minimizing the overall house energy requirements. On the other hand in hot climates temperatures excess heat can create uncomfortable indoor conditions. Passive alternatives to air conditioning systems such as temperature-dependent venting have been shown to be effective in regions with cooling needs.<ref>Reda, F., Tuominen, P., Hedman, Å., Ibrahim, M.G.E.: Low-energy residential buildings in New Borg El Arab: Simulation and survey based energy assessment. Energy and Buildings, Volume 93, 15 April 2015, Pages 65-82.</ref> Other techniques to combat excessive solar heat gains include [[Brise soleil]]s, [[tree]]s, attached [[pergola]]s with [[vine]]s, [[vertical garden]]s, [[green roof]]s among others.
Low-energy houses can be constructed from dense or lightweight materials, but some internal [[thermal mass]] is normally incorporated to reduce summer peak temperatures, maintain stable winter temperatures, and prevent possible overheating in spring or autumn before the higher [[effect of sun angle on climate|sun angle]] "shades" mid-day wall exposure and window penetration. Exterior wall color, when the surface allows choice, for reflection or absorption [[insolation]] qualities depends on the predominant year-round ambient outdoor temperature. The use of [[deciduous]] trees and wall [[Trellis (architecture)|trellis]]ed or self attaching vines can assist in climates not at the temperature extremes. *[[Sustainable landscaping]] *[[Sustainable landscape architecture]] *[[Sustainable gardening]] *[[Rainwater harvesting]] *[[Water conservation]]
===Lighting and electrical appliances=== {{See also|Daylighting|Passive daylighting|Active daylighting}} To minimize the total primary energy consumption, the many [[Passive daylighting|passive]] and [[Active daylighting|active]] [[daylighting]] techniques are the first daytime solution to employ. For low light level days, non-daylighted spaces, and nighttime; the use of creative-sustainable [[lighting design]] using low-energy sources such as 'standard voltage' [[compact fluorescent lamp]]s and [[solid-state lighting]] with [[Light-emitting diode]]-[[LED lamp]]s, [[organic light-emitting diode]]s, and [[Solid-state lighting#Polymer light-emitting diodes|PLED - polymer light-emitting diodes]]; and 'low voltage' [[electrical filament]]-[[Incandescent light bulb]]s, and [[Ceramic discharge metal halide lamp|compact Metal halide]], [[Xenon arc lamps|Xenon]] and [[Halogen lamps]], can be used.
Solar powered exterior circulation, security, and [[landscape lighting]] - with [[photovoltaic cell]]s on each fixture or connecting to a central [[Solar panel]] system, are available for [[garden]]s and outdoor needs. Low voltage systems can be used for more controlled or independent illumination, while still using less electricity than conventional fixtures and lamps. Timers, [[motion detection]] and [[natural lighting|natural light]] operation sensors reduce energy consumption, and [[light pollution]] even further for a Low-energy house setting.
[[Home appliance|Appliance]] [[consumer product]]s meeting independent energy efficiency testing and receiving [[Ecolabel]] [[certification mark]]s for reduced electrical-'natural-gas' consumption and product manufacturing [[carbon emission label]]s are preferred for use in Low-energy houses. The ecolabel certification marks of [[Energy Star]] and [[EKOenergy]] are examples. *[[:Category:Energy-saving lighting|Energy-saving lighting]] *[[:Category:Lighting|Lighting]] *[[:Category:Windows|Windows]] *[[:Category:Energy conservation|Energy conservation]] *[[:Category:Alternative energy|Alternative energy]]

==External links== * [http://bigee.net/ bigEE - Your guide to energy efficiency in buildings] * [http://task40.iea-shc.org/ IEA research program "Net Zero Energy Solar Buildings"] * [http://www.ecbcs.org IEA Energy Conservation in Buildings and Community Systems Programme.] * [http://www.commonfire.org/green Common Fire Foundation] Comprehensive Overview of Green Building, plus info on the net zero energy "Greenest Building in the Eastern US" (non-profit) * [http://www.minergie.com MINERGIE (official site)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100407123201/http://www.greenbuildingsolutions.org/s_greenbuilding/doc.asp?CID=2150&DID=9058 Article on Low-Energy Housing] * [http://www.enob.info/en/net-zero-energy-buildings/ Net zero energy- , energy-plus or climate-neutral buildings in the next generation of electricity grids]

{{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = Mansour Gholami | image = منصور غلامی.jpg | imagesize = | smallimage = | caption = | order = | office = [[Ministry of Science, Research and Technology (Iran)|Minister of Science]] | term_start = 29 October 2017 | term_end = | president = [[Hassan Rouhani]] | predecessor = [[Seyed Zia Hashemi]] (acting) | successor = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1953}} | birth_place = [[Bahar, Iran|Bahar]], [[Hamedan Province|Hamedan]], [[Iran]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Tarbiat Modares University]]
[[University of Adelaide]] | nationality = [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] | party = [[Islamic Association of University Instructors]] }} '''Mansour Gholami''' ({{lang-fa|منصور غلامی}}, born 1953 in [[Hamedan]]) is an Iranian professor, politician and the current [[Ministry of Science, Research and Technology (Iran)|Minister of Science]], a position he held since 29 October 2017.{{cite news|url=http://www.irna.ir/en/News/82712387|work=IRNA|title=Iran parliament approves new energy, science ministers|date=29 October 2017|access-date=29 October 2017|editor=Hamid Shamlou|translator=Hamdollah Emadi Heydari|id=82712387 }} He was Chancellor of [[Bu-Ali Sina University]] in two terms, first from 1997 until 2004 and the second from 2014 until 2017. == References == {{reflist}} {{iran-politician-stub}} {{Rouhani cabinet}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gholami, Mansour}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Science ministers]] [[Category:Islamic Association of University Instructors politicians]]

{{notability|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox dot-com company | name = NewsPlus | logo = | company_type = [[Private company|Private]] | traded_as = | foundation = | dissolved = | location = [[Singapore]], [[Hyderabad]] | locations = | incorporated = | area_served = [[India]], [[SE Asia]], [[United States]] | founder = {{unbulleted list|Srini Koppolu|Vasudeva Varma}} | chairman = | chairperson = | president = | CEO = [[Srini Koppolu]] | MD = | GM = | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | company_slogan = | url = | programming_language = | ipv6 = | alexa = | website_type = | advertising = | registration = | num_users = | language = | launch_date = August 2015 | current_status = active | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = | footnotes = | intl = | website = }}
'''<big>NewsPlus</big>''' is a [[news aggregator]] company based in [[Singapore]] and [[Hyderabad]]. It aggregates content from news sites, social media and blogs. The service can be accessed via [[web browser]], or via mobile apps for [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]].
== Languages and Countries == NewsPlus is localized into 10 languages.
NewsPlus brings news for India, USA, Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, Pakistan, South Africa, and the local news for all major cities and towns.
==History== NewsPlus app was originally launched under name of Veooz in August 2015 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/features/smartbuy/tech-news/indian-startup-launches-global-news-app-veooz/article7469427.ece|title=Indian start-up launches global news app Veooz|date=2015-07-27|publisher=The Hindu Business Line}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://businesstoday.intoday.in/story/koppolu-microsoft-india-development-md-launches-news-app/1/222297.html|title=Koppolu, former Microsoft India Development Center MD, launches news app|date=2015-07-31|publisher=Business Today}}</ref> Since then product evolved significantly, with support for additional languages, and addition features like, magazines, direct sharing, social features.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links ==
[[Category:Technology websites]] [[Category:News aggregators]] [[Category:Social media]] [[Category:Websites about digital media]]

The '''Open Document Format Alliance''' ('''ODF Alliance''') is a [[Washington, D.C.]]-based [[lobbying]] organization established by [[IBM]], [[Sun Microsystems]] and SIIA to "promote and advance the use of [[OpenDocument Format]] (ODF) as the primary document format for governments" {{cite web | url = http://www.odfalliance.org/mission.php | title = ODF Alliance Mission Statement | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Author Unknown}} Although originally focused on promotion of ODF "via legislation or by executive policy decision",{{cite web | url = http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=printArticleBasic&articleId=9022878 | title = Microsoft trounces pro-ODF forces in state battles over open document formats | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Eric Lai and Gregg Keizer}} the ODF Alliance also did extensive PR and lobbying in opposition to the [[Microsoft]]-backed [[Office Open XML]] standard.{{cite web | url = http://www.odfalliance.org/resources/TheCaseAgainstOOXML.pdf | title = The Case against OOXML | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Author Unknown}} Founded by IBM, Sun and 33 other companies and organizations on March 3, 2006,{{cite web | url = http://www.odfalliance.org/press/Release%2020060303.pdf | title = Alliance Formed to Promote Improved Access to and Retrieval of Electronic Government Documents | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Author Unknown}} the Alliance now boasts more than 500 members.{{cite web | url = http://www.odfalliance.org/press/Release20080103.pdf | title = Significant Milestones, Continued Momentum for ODF Highlighted in 2007 Annual Report | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Author Unknown}} However, funding sources are not itemized in the organization's 2007 annual report, so membership financial participation is unclear. The ODF Alliance does not give a physical location on their website, but from documents filed with the [[State of New York]],{{cite web | url = http://www.odfalliance.org/resources/NY_RFPC.pdf | title = CIO/OFT Request for Public Comment (RFPC) # 122807 | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Mario Marchich}} the organization appears to be headquartered on the 6th floor of [[1090 Vermont Avenue]] NW in Washington, DC 20005, sharing offices with the [[Software and Information Industry Association]] (SIIA), one of the original backers of the ODF Alliance. ==Staff== The executive director is [[Marino Marcich]], who served for four years in the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]]'s [[United States Department of State|State Department]] prior to joining the ODF Alliance. While at the Department of State, he was part of former [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Colin Powell|Colin Powell's]] inner circle.{{cite web | url = http://www.spinwatch.org/content/view/1849/9/ | archive-url = https://archive.is/20070616040819/http://www.spinwatch.org/content/view/1849/9/ | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2007-06-16 | title = Spinwatch Lobbying World | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Spinwatch}} Prior to joining the Bush administration, "Marcich also served as the [[National Association of Manufacturers]] (NAM) assistant vice president for international economic affairs, leading key lobby campaigns for [[World Trade Organization]] accession and trade-promotion authority."{{cite web | url = http://www.spinwatch.org/content/view/1849/9/ | archive-url = https://archive.is/20070616040819/http://www.spinwatch.org/content/view/1849/9/ | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2007-06-16 | title = Spinwatch Lobbying World | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Spinwatch}} Public Relations for the ODF Alliance are handled by [[Rational PR]], headed by Kathyrn Brownlee. Although Rational PR does not list the ODF Alliance as a client as of April 2008, SIIA is listed.{{cite web | url = http://www.rationalpr.com/whoweworkfor.html | title = Rational PR: who we work for | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Author Unknown}} ==Structure== The ODF Alliance [[website]] provides no information on funding or management structure. At this time, the website lists 6 "national chapters" outside of the United States; [[Brazil]], [[Europe]], [[India]], [[Malaysia]], [[Poland]] and [[Portugal]], but it is unclear if those chapter organizations have any input into the policy decisions of the organization.{{cite web | url = http://www.odfalliance.org/memberlist.php | title = Memberlist | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Author Unknown | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080502064623/http://www.odfalliance.org/memberlist.php | archivedate = 2008-05-02 | df = }} ==Activities== '''ODF Preferences'''
The ODF Alliance has also been very active in [[lobbying]] U.S. State and International [[governments]] on ODF issues to promote [[legislative]] mandates for the use of the ODF document format. The ODF Alliance has provided public testimony in the following fora: * 2008 April 9: Testimony before the Government Reform Committee, State of Texas;{{cite web | url = http://consortiuminfo.org/standardsblog/article.php?story=2008040911004525| title = At the Texas Hearing on Electronic Documents | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Andy Updegrove}} * 2007 February 7: Newsletter to ODF Alliance Members;{{cite web | url = http://www.odfalliance.org/press/Newsletter20070208.pdf| title = ODF Advances in Minnesota, Texas | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Andy Updegrove}} * 2007 April 17: AB 1668 California Assembly Bill: Bill Analysis.{{cite web | url = http://info.sen.ca.gov/pub/07-08/bill/asm/ab_1651-1700/ab_1668_cfa_20070416_103510_asm_comm.html| title = AB 1668 California Assembly Bill: Bill Analysis | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Juan Arambula, Chair}} '''Anti-OOXML'''
During late 2007 though 2008, the ODF Alliance was focused on lobbying ISO members in order to prevent OOXML from being accepted by [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]]. * Ongoing: OOXML Updates and Analysis;{{cite web | url = http://www.odfalliance.org/resources.php| title = OOXML Updates and Analysis | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Unknown}} * 2007 June 7: "ODF Alliance posts documents about OOXML/OpenXML/whatever";{{cite web | url = http://www.sutor.com/newsite/blog-open/?p=1694| title = ODF Alliance posts documents about OOXML/OpenXML/whatever | accessdate = 2008-04-23 | author = Bob Sutor, IBM}} * 2008 February 25: [[Open Forum Europe]] [[Geneva]] Conference.{{cite web|url=http://www.openforumeurope.org/geneva/geneva-supporters.pdf/view |title=Open Forum Europe Supporters |accessdate=2008-04-23 |author=OFE |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827162909/http://www.openforumeurope.org/geneva/geneva-supporters.pdf/view |archivedate=August 27, 2008 }} '''Last know Newsletter'''
The ODF Alliance website's last snapshot saved by Archive.org dates back from March 24, 2013. Even then, the latest published news was the "ODFA Newsletter" from October 2010, implying the Alliance ceased to operate long before the website was shut down. During 2014 the domain name odfalliance.org went from displaying error pages to briefly displaying ODF-related news, and to finally housing legal information about injury lawyers. In 2015 odfalliance.org housed cigar news. No news could be found about exactly when or why the ODFA was dissolved. ==References== {{Reflist | 2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090910043707/http://slashdot.org/articles/06/03/05/1721258.shtml ODF Alliance, Who, What, Where (and Why?)] - [[Slashdot]] commentary. [[Category:Free and open-source software organizations]] [[Category:Open standards]]

{{mergeto|poker|date=August 2018}} The following is a list of equipment used for a game of [[poker]]:
* '''Cards:''' Standard [[playing card]]s are used. In home games it is common to have two decks with distinct backs, and to shuffle the unused deck while each hand is in progress. Casinos typically change decks every few hours, to limit the wear of the cards. It is not unusual for paper cards to become bent quickly, as players often read their "hole" cards by peeking at the corner rather than lifting the card. Card quality can be preserved for longer if players agree not to bend cards, and proper [[shuffling]] techniques are used. * '''Cut card (or postilion):''' This is a plain opaque plastic card, the same size and shape as a playing card. The dealer will place the cut card on the table so that the top cards in the [[cut (cards)|cut]] can be placed on it; this prevents the accidental exposure of the bottom card when the dealer picks up the deck after the cut has been completed. While rarely used in home games, the cut card is universal in casino play.<ref>{{cite book|page=30|title=52 Ways to Cheat at Poker: How to Spot Them, Foil Them, and Defend Yourself Against Them|author=Allan Kronzek|isbn=0452289114|year=2008|publisher=Plume}}</ref> *'''Card protectors:''' In games where all of a player's cards are facedown, some players use items like specialty chips or glass figures to place on top of their cards to protect them from being accidentally discarded.<ref>{{cite book|page=192|title=Serious Poker|author=Daniel Y. Kimberg|year=2002|isbn=1886070164|publisher=Conjelco}}</ref> * '''[[Button (poker)#Other buttons|Lammers]]:''' Lammers are plastic, chip-shaped tokens with text written on them. Most commonly used is a dealer button with either the word "DEALER" or a "D" written on it; this item (also known as the ''buck'') indicates who shall deal next. In a casino setting, lammers are also used to indicate which variant is being used, whose turn it is to pay the [[Blind (poker)|blind]], etc., and lammers are also a name for "chips" awarded in satellite tournaments as buy-in chips to larger tournaments.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Professional Poker Dealer's Handbook|authors=Dan Paymar, Donna Harris, and Mason Malmuth|year=1998|isbn=1880685183}}</ref> * '''[[Poker chip]]s:''' Currency is difficult to stack or handle, so most poker games are played with '''chips''', or coin-shaped tokens of uniform size and weight, usually 39mm wide and anywhere from 5 to 16 grams in weight, whose money value is determined by their color. Historically, poker chips were made of [[bone]]; however, modern casino chips are often made of clay or a clay composite and are considered the most upscale variety of poker chip; other high-end chips are made of ceramic. Plastic chips are also available, at a wide variety of quality levels. * '''[[Poker table]]:''' A typical poker game will have between two and ten players. A padded table top is preferred to facilitate picking up chips and cards. * '''[[Timer]]:''' If playing a [[poker tournament]], a timer is used to count down periods in which the blinds are at certain levels. When the timer reaches 0:00, the blinds go to a higher level.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Poker gameplay and terminology]] [[Category:Game equipment]]

[[File:Grosvenor Museums - Wasserröhren.jpg|thumb|Water pipe with Latin inscription from the reign of [[Vespasian]]. The text is unusual for being sunk into the surface and its sizable length of 1 m.<ref>{{harvnb|Brekle|2010|pp=433f.}}</ref>]]
A '''Roman lead pipe inscription''' is a [[Latin]] [[inscription]] on a [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] [[water pipe]] made of [[lead]] which provides brief information on its manufacturer and owner, often the reigning [[List of Roman Emperors|emperor]] himself as the supreme authority. The identification marks were created by full text [[Stamping (metalworking)|stamp]]s.<ref>{{harvnb|Brekle|2010|pp=419f., 436}}</ref>
== Manufacture of pipes == [[File:Lead pipe - Bath Roman Baths.jpg|thumb|upright|Uninscribed lead pipe with a folded seam, at the [[Roman Baths (Bath)|Roman thermae of Bath]], England]]
Lead, a product of the ancient [[silver]] smelting process, was produced in the [[Roman Empire]] with an estimated peak production of 80,000 metric tons per year – a truly industrial scale.<ref>{{harvnb|Hong|Candelone|Patterson|Boutron|1994|p=1841}}</ref> The metal was used along with other materials in the vast [[Roman aqueduct|water supply network of the Romans]] for the manufacture of water pipes, particularly for urban [[plumbing]].<ref>{{harvnb|Grewe|1985|p=59}}; {{harvnb|Hodge|1992|p=307}}</ref>
The method of manufacturing the lead pipes is recorded by [[Vitruvius]] and [[Frontinus]].<ref>{{harvnb|Hodge|1992|p=309}}</ref> The lead was poured into sheets of a uniform 3m length, which were bent to form a cylinder and soldered at the seam.<ref>{{harvnb|Hodge|1992|pp=309–314}}</ref> The lead pipes could range in size from approximately {{convert|1.3|cm|1|abbr=on}} up to {{convert|57|cm|0|abbr=on}} diameter depending on the required rate of flow.<ref>{{harvnb|Hodge|1992|p=297, table 209}}</ref>
== Creation of inscriptions == Since the 19th century, the hypothesis has occasionally been put forward that the Roman inscriptions were created by movable type [[printing]].<ref>Lanciani 1881, p. 416, {{harvnb|Pace|1986|p=78}}</ref> A recent investigation by the typesetter and linguist [[Herbert Brekle]], however, concludes that all material evidence points to the use of common text stamps.<ref>{{harvnb|Brekle|2010|p=436}}: {{quote|On balance, material evidence, practical and economical considerations, as well as the available data, clearly support the notion that text stamps were employed.}}</ref> Brekle describes the manufacturing method as follows:
{{quote|A stamp ([[punch (typography)|punch]]) which has the text carved in [[high-relief]] and in right reading is pressed into the slightly moist sand or clay of the mould, thus producing a reverse image of the text ([[matrix (printing)|matrix]]) in [[bas-relief]]. After the molten lead is poured out in the mould, the inscription appears raised in high-relief on the surface of the lead pipe. This is today considered the most plausible hypothesis for the creation of such inscriptions (full text stamp).<ref name="Brekle 2010, 419">{{harvnb|Brekle|2010|p=419}}</ref>}}
[[File:Bleirohr LegioXIV Wiesbaden.jpg|thumb|left|Lead pipe stamp of the [[Legio XIV Gemina]]]]
Brekle lists the following reasons for the employment of stamps and against that of movable type: for printing on lead sheets the way the Romans created them, it would be much more practical to use single stamp blocks than sets of individual letters, since the latter would be unstable and would have required a clamp or some similar mechanism to maintain the necessary cohesion.<ref>{{harvnb|Brekle|2010|p=420}}</ref> Neither impressions of such clamps nor of the fine lines between the individual letters typical for the use of movable type are discernible in the inscriptions.<ref name="Brekle 2010, 431">{{harvnb|Brekle|2010|p=431}}</ref> By contrast, the outer rim of one examined stamp block left a raised rectangular edge running around the inscription text, thus providing positive evidence for the use of such a printing device.<ref>{{harvnb|Brekle|2010|p=435}}</ref>
In addition, evidence of the poor positioning of movable type, such as individual letters tilting to the right or left or deviating from the baseline – something which could have been expected to occur at least in a few extant specimens – is notably absent.<ref name="Brekle 2010, 431"/> In those inscriptions where the letters are not properly aligned, the entire text is blurred, which clearly points to the use of full text stamps.<ref>{{harvnb|Brekle|2010|pp=431f.}}</ref> Finally, it needs to be considered that archaeological excavations have never unearthed ancient sets of movable type, whereas moulds with reversed inscription texts for stamp printing have indeed been recovered.<ref>{{harvnb|Brekle|2010|p=426}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Plumbing]] * [[Roman aqueduct]]
== References == {{Reflist|33em}}
== Sources == * {{Citation | last = Brekle | first = Herbert E. | editor1-last = Hanneforth | editor1-first = Thomas | editor2-last = Fanselow | editor2-first = Gisbert | authorlink = Herbert E. Brekle | contribution = Herstellungstechniken von Inschriften auf römischen Wasserleitungsrohren aus Blei | title = Language and Logos. Studies in Theoretical and Computational Linguistics | publisher = Akademie Verlag | place = Berlin | series = studia grammatica | volume = 72 | isbn = 978-3-05-004931-1 | year = 2010 | pages = 419–437 }} * {{Citation | last = Grewe | first = Klaus | title = Planung und Trassierung römischer Wasserleitungen | place = Wiesbaden | publisher = Chmielorz | year = 1985 | isbn = 3-87124-025-7 }} * {{Citation | last = Hodge | first = A. Trevor | title = Roman Aqueducts & Water Supply | place = London | publisher = Duckworth | year = 1992 | isbn = 0-7156-2194-7 }} * {{Citation | last1 = Hong | first1 = Sungmin | last2 = Candelone | first2 = Jean-Pierre | last3 = Patterson | first3 = Clair C. | last4 = Boutron | first4 = Claude F. | title = Greenland Ice Evidence of Hemispheric Lead Pollution Two Millennia Ago by Greek and Roman Civilizations | journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume = 265 | issue = 5180 | pages = 1841–1843 | year = 1994 | doi = 10.1126/science.265.5180.1841 | pmid=17797222 }} * [[Rodolfo Lanciani|Lanciani, R.]]: "Topografia di Roma antica. I commentarii di Frontino intorno le acque e gli acquedotti. Silloge epigrafica aquaria", in: ''Memorie della Reale Accademia dei Lincei'', Serie III, Volume IV, Classe di Scienze Morali, Rom 1881 (Reprint: Quasar publishing house, 1975), pp. 215–616 * {{Citation | last = Pace | first = Pietrantonio | authorlink = Pietrantonio Pace | title = Gli acquedotti di Roma e il Aquaeductu di Frontino | edition = 2nd | place = Rome | publisher = Art Studio S. Eligio | year = 1986 }}
